entry.title: Custom Form with Custom Data Source in SAP Public Cloud (Grow with SAP)
entry.content:
INTRODUCTION

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, there are scenarios where standard output forms and data sources do not fully meet business requirements.

This blog post explains how to create a custom output form using a custom data source in SAP S/4HANA Cloud (Grow with SAP).

The form is developed directly in the S/4HANA Cloud tenant. Please note that this blog post does not cover ‚ÄúSAP Forms service by Adobe‚Äù on SAP Business Technology Platform. Instead, it focuses on form development within the public cloud system itself (Developer Extensibility)

When Should You Follow This Approach?

You should consider creating a custom form with a custom data source in the following scenarios:

  • SAP has not provided a standard data source for the required business object.
    Examples include:
    • Purchase Requisition Output
    • Supplier Invoice Output
  • You have developed a custom application or custom business object, and an output form is required.
    Since the development is custom, there will naturally be no standard form or data source available for output generation

In such cases, defining a custom data source and binding it to a custom form becomes the correct and often the only viable approach.

When Should You Not Follow This Approach?

You should avoid this approach when a standard solution already exists:

  • If SAP provides a standard data source and a standard form template, you should use them instead of creating custom ones,
    Example: Purchase Order outputs already have standard data sources and form templates available.
  • When standard data sources are available, always prefer the ‚ÄúForm Template‚Äù Fiori app to customize the output.
    Customization of Content Form Templates - SAP S/4HANA Finance

Prerequisites 

Tools

  • Adobe LiveCycle Designer
    Required for designing and modifying Adobe-based output forms. The tool is used to define the layout, structure, and binding of the form fields to the data source.
  • ABAP Development Toolkit (ADT)
    Required for designing and modifying Adobe-based output forms. The tool is used to define the layout, structure, and binding of the form fields to the data source.

Skills

  • Knowledge on Adobe Form
  • Knowledge on RAP Development Framework

Code References

All example code referenced in this article is available in the Git repository linked below. To keep the blog post concise and focused, the source code is not reproduced here in full, as including it would unnecessarily lengthen the post.
GitHub - gourabdey-sap/form-development-in-s4hc: Custom Form Development with Custom Data Source in S4HC

TECHNICAL IMPLEMENTATION

As an example for custom form development using a custom data source, we will use the Purchase Requisition (PR) form. This example is chosen because the Purchase Requisition process is well known and familiar to most readers, making it easier to understand and relate to the concepts discussed.

Step 1 - Custom CDS View Creation

We will create a RAP BO for Purchase Requisition form output requirement. I usually prefer defining a Root CDS view to keep the design future-proof. This approach allows for easy functional enhancements later without requiring changes to the existing CDS hierarchy.

That said, if your objective is only to call the form, a standard CDS view is sufficient. In such cases, creating a Root CDS view (RAP Business Object) is not mandatory.

We will create two interface CDS views and two corresponding consumption CDS views:

  • One set for header data
  • One set for item data

The source code for the CDS can be found in GitHub Repo .

Step 2 - Marking the Header Consumption CDS as Form Data Provider

Add the following annotation to the header consumption CDS view. This annotation is required only for the header consumption view and must not be added to the item CDS view

@ObjectModel.supportedCapabilities: [ #OUTPUT_FORM_DATA_PROVIDER  ]

Step 3 - Creating Form Data Provider (Data Source)

Next, we need to create a Service Definition to act as the form data provider (data source). Both the header and item entities must be exposed in this service definition. 

An important point to note is the leading entity annotation, defined using @ObjectModel.leadingEntity.name

@EndUserText.label: 'PR Form Data Provider'
@ObjectModel.leadingEntity.name: 'ZMM_C_PRHEADER'
define service ZMM_PR_FORM_DATA {
  expose ZMM_C_PrHeader as Header;
  expose ZMM_C_PrItem   as Item;
}

Key Point Consideration:

  • Only one CDS entity must be designated as the Form Data Provider. In this scenario, the header CDS view (ZMM_C_PrHeader) is the sole data provider and is annotated with @ObjectModel.supportedCapabilities: [ #OUTPUT_FORM_DATA_PROVIDER].
    The item CDS view must not contain this annotation.
  • The Service Definition should have the leading entity defined in upper case. The Data Definition name of the header view is ZMM_C_PrHeader still, the leading entity has to be provided as ZMM_C_PRHEADER.
@ObjectModel.leadingEntity.name: 'ZMM_C_PRHEADER'‚Äã
  • Service Binding creation is not required for rendering the form. Only Service Binding is enough,
    But, still in this blog post Service Binding will be required for generation of RAP Application. 

Step 4 - Form Creation

Create new Form using Path: Right Click on Package > New > Other ABAP Repository Object > Form. Provide the form name as required. I have given as ZMM_PR_OUTPUT.

Data Provider: 

Select the data provider as the Service Definition been created in Step 3. In this example, this will be ZMM_PR_FORM_DATA. 

Save the form (Ctrl/Cmd + S). 

Please note: The form cannot be activated yet as the layout is still not developed. 

Step 5 - Download XML Schema (XSD File)

To download the XSD file of form, click on "Download Schema" button.

Click on export and give the file name. I have given the file name as "PR Schema.xsd".

Step 6 - Create Form Layout

Open Adobe LiveCycle Designer (ALD) locally in the system. You can search for the application "Adobe LiveCycle Designer" in your system and should be able to open it, provided this is installed locally in your system.

Once the Adobe LiveCycle Designer is open, click on New Form. Or alternatively you can use the menu File > New Form (Ctrl/Cmd + N) 

Select the orientation as required and click on Finish.

Use the menu File > New Data Connection to link to the XSD file.

Select the XSD file downloaded from Step 5. Click on finish.

The field details can be seen the Data View tab. If you don't have data view tab, then you can add it from the menu Windows > Data View

Rename the Page and bind it to the header Node.

Then save the form as XDP file (Ctrl/Cmd + S).

Step 7 - Designing the Form

As both form is created and the connection is established with XSD file, we can work on the layout development as required.

As an example, I will have a very basic layout where some of the fields from header will be bound and we will have a table which will have item details. 

You would need the data in XML format. We will download it subsequent section. We will also see how to preview the form locally in the system. 

Step 8 - Generate Sample Data

Right click on Preview PDF tab > Select Preview Tab

Click on Generate Preview Data > Click on the button below Data File Name

Provide the name of the file and Click Save. 

Then click on Generate Button, which will generate some sample data. Click on Ok.

With this we have some example data been generated and we can Preview the form locally.

Step 9 - Preview the Form

Click on the Preview Tab to have a look at the form layout been developed.

This is how the form layout appears locally during preview. Some fields are displayed in light blue in the local preview; however, when the form is executed within S/4HANA Cloud (S/4HC), this blue coloring will not be visible.

The sample forms, example data and XSD scheme can be found in GitHub Repo 

Step 10 - Upload the Form in S4

Open the form been created in Step 4 and upload the developed form using Upload Layout. 

Now you should be able to activate the form.

So, we have successfully created the form and uploaded in S4HC.

Step 11 - Adding Attachment Related field in Header Consumption View

For showing the attachment using CDS, we would need below 3 fields

  • File Name - Name of the file
  • Mime Type - For PDF, this will be always
  • Attachment - The PR Output PDF

So, we will achieve this by using virtual element of CDS. 

Important Annotation:

Virtual Field

@ObjectModel.virtualElementCalculatedBy: 'ABAP:ZCL_MM_PR_FORM'

Attachment Field

@Semantics.largeObject:{
  mimeType: 'MimeType',
  fileName: 'FileName',
  contentDispositionPreference: #ATTACHMENT
}

Mime Type

@Semantics.mimeType: true

CDS Source Code

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Purchase Requisition Header'
@ObjectModel.supportedCapabilities: [ #OUTPUT_FORM_DATA_PROVIDER ]
@Metadata.allowExtensions: true
define root view entity ZMM_C_PrHeader
  provider contract transactional_query
  as projection on ZMM_I_PrHeader
{
  key     PurchaseRequisition,
          PurReqnDescription,
          PurchaseRequisitionType,
          LastChangeDateTime,
          @ObjectModel.virtualElementCalculatedBy: 'ABAP:ZCL_MM_PR_FORM'
  virtual FileName   : abap.char( 50 ),
          @ObjectModel.virtualElementCalculatedBy: 'ABAP:ZCL_MM_PR_FORM'
          @Semantics.mimeType: true
  virtual MimeType   : abap.char( 50 ),
          @ObjectModel.virtualElementCalculatedBy: 'ABAP:ZCL_MM_PR_FORM'
          @Semantics.largeObject:{
            mimeType: 'MimeType',
            fileName: 'FileName',
            contentDispositionPreference: #ATTACHMENT
          }
  virtual Attachment : abap.rawstring( 0 ),
          /* Associations */
          _Item : redirected to composition child ZMM_C_PrItem
}

Step 12 - Logic for Virtual Elements 

The calculation class for virtual element should implement the interface if_sadl_exit_calc_element_read.

The interface has 2 methods.

  • get_calculation_info :
    • The fields which are used in the logic required to be added to the field et_requested_orig_elements.
    • For our case, only Purchase Requisition number is enough.
  • calculate:
    • The actual logic for virtual fields will go here. 
    • The required fields have to be populated in internal table ct_calculated_data.

Complete code for the class is available here.

Step 13 - Calling the Adobe Form

Rending the Form (line no 23-31)

  • The form is rendered using the method cl_fp_ads_util=>render_pdf.
  • This requires the data and the layout.

Reading data in XML format (line 9-14)

  • The XML data are being read using the object of CL_FP_FDP_SERVICES. 
  • It requires the key of the Root/Header CDS, which is defined as lead entity in the Service Definition in Step 3. In our case, only Purchase Requisition is the key. If multiple keys are there, value should be passed for all keys.
  • The Purchase requisition data is fetched in the line 13 in the variable LV_DATA in XSTRING format.

Reading data in Form Layout (line no 19)

  • We would also need the form layout (Adobe Form which was designed and uploaded in Step 10) to render the form.
  • The form layout is fetched and assigned to LV_XML in XSTRING format.

Getting reference to Form API

  • Passing the Service Definition created in Step 3 to get the reference.
  • This API will be used to get the data from the Form Data Provider in XML format.
  • The parameter iv_max_depth represents navigation level. In this example, we have Header and Item so, 1 level depth should be fine
  METHOD get_pdf.

    mc_duplicate_call = abap_true.

    DATA(lo_fdp_api) = cl_fp_fdp_services=>get_instance(
      iv_max_depth          = 1
      iv_service_definition = `ZMM_PR_FORM_DATA` ).

    DATA(lt_keys)    = lo_fdp_api->get_keys( ).

    lt_keys[ name = 'PURCHASEREQUISITION' ]-value = im_v_pr.

    DATA(lv_data) = lo_fdp_api->read_to_xml_v2(
      it_select = lt_keys
    ).

    DATA(lv_string) = cl_abap_conv_codepage=>create_in( )->convert( lv_data ).

    DATA(lv_xml) = lo_fdp_api->get_xsd_v2( ).

    DATA(lv_string2) = cl_abap_conv_codepage=>create_in( )->convert( lv_xml ).

    DATA(lo_reader) = cl_fp_form_reader=>create_form_reader( `ZMM_PR_OUTPUT` ).

    DATA(ls_layout) = lo_reader->get_layout( ).

    cl_fp_ads_util=>render_pdf( EXPORTING iv_xml_data   = lv_data
                                          iv_xdp_layout = ls_layout
                                          iv_locale     = 'en_US'
                                IMPORTING ev_pdf        = rt_v_pdf
                                         ).

    mc_duplicate_call = abap_false.

  ENDMETHOD.

Step 14 - Service Binding

Create a Service Binding for the RAP application. This should be OData v4, as attachment does not work in OData V2 using CDS Annotation.

Preview the Application.:

Step 15 - Download the Form

Click the link in the Attachment column of any row to download the PDF. Mission accomplished! üöÄ

CONCLUSION

Below is the recap of the activities done so far

  • Created the necessary CDS views to fetch the required data, covering both header and item information.
  • Designated the header consumption CDS view as the Form Data Provider using the appropriate annotation.
  • Created the Adobe Form in SAP S/4HANA Cloud and exported the corresponding XSD schema.
  • Designed the form layout locally using Adobe LiveCycle Designer, with the XSD schema used for data binding.
  • Generated sample XML data locally and used it to preview and validate the form layout.
  • Uploaded the completed form layout back into S/4HANA Cloud and successfully activated the form.
  • Created the virtual elements in the consumption view for attachments. Logic has been added fill the Filename, Mime Type and PDF.
  • Service Binding has been created for the for the RAP application (OData V4) and able to download the PDF which is a custom form with custom data source.

One More Thing‚Ä¶ üß† (For the Curious Minds)

If you‚Äôve made it this far, here‚Äôs a small challenge for fellow SAP explorers: SAP standard output transactions allow you to download the form XML using the magical command #&&DOWNLOAD_FORM_DATA_XML&&#

Now the fun part:

üëâWhy not bring the same superpower to your custom form?

Try adding a provision to download the XML data using the very same command‚Äînot a workaround, not a shortcut, but exactly the SAP way.
Bonus points if your implementation is so seamless that it feels like it shipped straight from Walldorf üòâ

Signing Off

Shared from experience. Use it, challenge it, and improve it‚Äîlet‚Äôs grow together with SAP Grow.

entry.title: Re: Understanding the Belgium B2B e-Invoicing Mandate and the Plant Abroad Scenario
entry.content:
Hi,

To enable Plant Abroad scenarios for incoming invoices, please ensure the following configuration is applied:

  1. Navigate to View Cluster VC_EDOMSGTYPE.
  2. For the message types BE_MESSAGE_PULL and BE_RESPONSE_PULL, select the check-box ‚ÄúPl. Abr‚Äù.

If this configuration is not maintained, DRC Cloud will display the following error when processing incoming invoices:
‚ÄúSelect Company codes only for BE.‚Äù

Best Regards,

Daniel

entry.title: Re: How to Take SAP‚Äôs New Performance-Based Certification Exams
entry.content:
Thanks @Amin_Omidy for your blog, it certainly clarifies the process, and I would certainly recommend to use the yoodil.ai just to get familiar with the platform if this is your first time for the new assessment. I have a few questions which am sure others will be asking as well:

  1. Case Study Availability: Just to clarify, was the case study provided, but I have heard of other having difficulty to locate within the platform?
  2. Download Status: Were you eventually able to find the file, and if so, were you able to download it or you can only read it online?
  3. Material Access: Are the exam materials made available for review before pressing the 'Start' button, or only after the exam has begun?
  4. Time Limit Clarification: Could you please clarify the reference to '24 hours'? My understanding is that there is a 2-hour limit to complete the exam (BTP Solution Architect) once started, so I am unclear what the 24-hour window refers to.
  5. Exam Retake: Is it correct that if we fail the first attempt, we are permitted to retake the exam immediately, provided we have sufficient time remaining? Specifically, the 2-hour window covers both the initial attempt and any necessary retakes? In this case how can we restart the exam to emsure its counted within the same attempt?
  6. Recording Procedures: If we are unable to find the required materials during the exam, are we permitted to stop the recording to search for them, or will stopping the recording end the session?

Many Thanks

How can I achieve this functionality?

entry.title: Batch Determination Failure During Outbound Delivery Creation
entry.content:
We are encountering a Production issue related to automatic batch determination during Outbound Delivery creation. Although all prerequisites appear to be correctly maintained, the system fails to determine batches automatically at the delivery creation stage. Manual batch determination at the same stage also fails‚Äîbut only for a few specific line items, and the occurrence appears random.

This issue does not impact all line items. Only certain items are affected, and no consistent pattern has been identified. We have also observed that under Batch Determination ‚Üí Selection Criteria at the line-item level of the Outbound Delivery, the system displays an incorrect date for the characteristic LOBM‚ÄëVFDAT (SLED) within the classification section. This incorrect value seems to influence batch selection. Additionally, when the delivery contains only one line item, batch determination works as expected.

However, once the delivery is saved and then reopened in change mode, the system correctly identifies and proposes batches when manual batch determination is executed. At this stage, the correct batches and split quantities are displayed, and the assignment can be completed without any issue.

entry.title: SAP Sustainability Footprint Management: Q4-25 Updates & Highlights
entry.content:
Happy New Year and cheers to a sustainable year ahead! As we kick off 2026, I‚Äôm back with my quarterly blog series about the latest innovations and highlights in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. In this edition, I‚Äôm covering:

  • Multi-Impact Categories
  • Streamlined Energy Management
  • Mass Upload and API Enhancements for GHG Data Collections
  • Emission Factor Management & AI-Mapping Enhancements
  • Other Release Highlights
  • Enablement Updates: Webinar, Learning Journey & Scenario Guide
  • BASF Coatings‚Äô Journey with SAP Sustainability Footprint Management
  • Additional Information

 

Multi-Impact Categories

One of the most significant innovations this quarter is the introduction of multi-impact categories in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, moving the product beyond carbon. Built on the same ERP-driven data foundation, governance model, and auditability, the latest updates extend the calculation engine to cover additional environmental impact categories. This lets you monitor a broader spectrum of environmental pressures without changing the way you integrate data or run calculations.

Think of multi-impact categories as different lenses on how your operations affect the Earth system. Aligned with planetary boundaries, they translate the data you already have into indicators for climate and other dimensions like land use, biosphere integrity, and biogeochemical flows. That means you can see where improvements in one area risk shifting burdens elsewhere ‚Äì and manage those trade-offs with real numbers.

This matters for reporting because one consistent dataset can now serve multiple frameworks (e.g., CSRD, SBTi FLAG), reducing parallel tools and strengthening credibility with synchronized, audit-ready figures for sustainability, finance, and controlling. But this also matters for decision-making because placing multi‚Äëimpact indicators alongside financial and operational KPIs brings sustainability into core business steering. A richer picture of environmental pressure helps identify where reductions also improve efficiency, resilience, and brand value ‚Äì and where hidden risks accumulate. This supports a shift from compliance‚Äëdriven reporting to performance‚Äëdriven management, where sustainability becomes a source of competitiveness and innovation.

Importantly, nothing changes in how you run the system. You still reuse ERP data, automate activity data collection, map to imported or pre‚Äëdelivered factors, and execute one centralized footprint calculation. The difference is that the same setup now delivers additional impact categories and result views, so your existing data and methods serve a growing list of corporate and product requirements ‚Äì without extra integrations or parallel logic.

Footprint Results with additional Impact Categories

To learn more about this innovation, its business rationale, and how it supports your reporting requirements, check out my deep dive blog post: Multi-Impact Categories in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. It also includes a step-by-step walkthrough of the overall workflow and the enhanced apps. For complete documentation and technical details, visit SAP Help: Calculating Footprints for Different Impact Categories.

We will also publish additional blog posts in the SAP Community, explaining in detail how you can map the multi-impact calculation results to various reporting requirements. Stay tuned!

 

Streamlined Energy Management

Managing energy data for footprint calculations has often been repetitive and time-consuming. Previously, you had to enter the same energy data and meter readings multiple times for different calculation variants, making workflows cumbersome and prone to errors. This complexity increased further when handling periodic meter readings and energy bills across multiple locations.

With the latest release, we‚Äôve simplified this process significantly: For all newly created footprint calculations, energy bills and meter readings are now managed separately from the footprint inventory using two new types of GHG data forms. This means you can collect periodic energy data via the Record GHG Data app and reuse it across multiple calculations without redundant entries. Data maintenance is now independent of calculation variants, saving time and improving consistency.

We‚Äôve also introduced more flexibility: you can calculate energy-related footprints based on energy sources only, without the need for an energy flow model, which is a major advantage for Corporate Carbon Footprint (CCF) calculations. The user experience has been improved in the Calculate Footprints app as well, with data readings displayed directly on the first page of the inventory for quick access.

In the following, I‚Äôll briefly summarize the required process steps and what has changed in the existing apps. For the full documentation, see Maintain Energy Bills and Meter Readings Using GHG Data Forms on SAP Help.

To use the new approach, start by preparing your footprint inventory scope. In the Manage Footprint Inventory Scopes app, activate form-based data collection for energy bills and meter readings. If you plan to use meter readings in your energy flow model, make sure to include Direct Emissions and Energy Consumptions under Value Chain Steps. For energy bills, this step isn‚Äôt required.

Define Footprint Inventory Scope with Form-Based Data Collection

Next, configure your energy sources in the Model Energy Flows app. When creating an energy source, choose Enter Energy Bills if you want to manage consumption through the Energy Bills form, or Use Meter Readings and Planned Consumptions for meter-based data. Meters themselves are created in the Manage Locations app and must be assigned to the relevant plants. If you include meters in your energy flow model, they need to be in place before creating the footprint inventory.

With the scope and energy sources ready, create GHG data collections for the relevant plants and periods in the Manage GHG Data Collections app. Then, record your periodic energy data in the Record GHG Data app. You can enter values directly in the UI. Alternatively, you can download the template for offline editing and mass upload, or you can use the enhanced API for automating data entry and connecting smart meters ‚Äì see the following chapter for details. Validation checks help ensure consistency, for example by flagging deviations greater than 30% from previous readings.

Record Meter Readings in GHG Data Form

Finally, run your calculation in the Calculate Footprints app. Newly created inventories no longer show separate tabs for energy bills and meter readings ‚Äì instead, these values are maintained in the GHG data forms, and the Data Readiness section provides an overview of form status and associated models.

Calculate Footprints: Data Readiness

 

Mass Upload and API Enhancements for GHG Data Collections

Managing GHG data across multiple locations and form types can be a challenge, especially when dealing with large datasets. That‚Äôs why we‚Äôre introducing a powerful new capability, allowing mass upload for GHG data forms. You can now upload different types of forms ‚Äì such as energy bills, meter readings, business activities, and waste data ‚Äì across locations using a single template in the Record GHG Data and Manage GHG Data Collections apps. The template includes tabs for each form type, making it easy to consolidate and manage data efficiently without repetitive manual entry. For all details, check SAP Help: Working with GHG Data Collections and Record GHG Data.

To take automation even further, the GHG Data Forms API has been enhanced with new endpoints and parameters for mass updates. This means you can retrieve and update forms programmatically, integrate with external systems, and even connect smart meters or IoT devices directly. Check out the API on SAP Business Accelerator Hub: GHG Data Forms.

These improvements reduce manual effort, increase accuracy, and save time. They‚Äôre also addressing several of the most requested features on SAP Influence.

 

Emission Factor Management & AI-Mapping Enhancements

High‚Äëquality emission factors are the backbone of accurate and audit‚Äëready footprint results. The broader and better your factor library, the fewer workarounds you need, the faster you can onboard, and the more confidently you can answer customer and regulatory requests. Last quarter, we‚Äôve expanded the default datasets, improved import templates and governance, and refined AI‚Äëassisted mapping ‚Äì so you can source, structure, and apply factors with less manual effort and higher precision.

With this release, the Manage Emission Factors app expands its default dataset substantially. We‚Äôve added two new source packages and refreshed an existing one to broaden coverage and improve alignment with logistics and fuel methodologies. Newly added are:

  • GLEC Framework (Smart Freight Centre): Harmonized logistics factors across road, rail, air, ocean/inland waterways, and parcel/last‚Äëmile; coverage for fuels and energy (TTW/WTT), logistics sites and equipment (warehousing, refrigeration, handling), plus rules for distance, allocation, and data quality aligned with ISO 14083.
  • German Environment Agency (Umweltbundesamt, UBA): Factors for fossil fuels including natural gas, hard coal, lignite, heating oils, diesel, gasoline, LPG, and more.

In addition, the UK DEFRA packages have been updated and now include the full set of emission factors. For more information, see Using Default Emission Factor Data on SAP Help.

To make onboarding and governance smoother, and to align with the latest features, we‚Äôve updated the import templates in the Manage Emission Factors app. The simple template (v3) and the LCA template (v5) now support impact categories beyond Climate Change, including the selection of an LCIA method and its characterization factor per dataset ‚Äì so you can manage multi‚Äëimpact content consistently. In the Dataset Sources tab, you can add a source URL to the dataset for traceability, and unit validation has been tightened via the Dimensions column. We also streamlined context fields by adding a drop-down list to the Boundary column and moving it to the Emission Dataset tab to keep dataset‚Äëlevel semantics in one place. For all changes, visit SAP Help: Emission Factors Data.

With the Custom Datasets feature in the Manage Emission Factor app, you can assemble component datasets into a single, composite dataset to derive an overall emission factor when a product or activity‚Äôs direct factor is unknown ‚Äì leveraging known emissions of its parts to enable accurate footprint calculations. Now, those custom datasets also support multi-impact categories, so you can use it also for emission factors beyond climate change. For more information, see Creating Custom Datasets and Emission Factors on SAP Help.

Custom Dataset with Multi-Impact Emission Factors

We‚Äôve also refined the AI-assisted emission factor mapping in the Manage Purchased Product Footprints app. This powerful feature suggests mappings between products (or product groups) from your ERP system and emission factors from LCA databases. A new option, Show Enhanced Footprint Suggestions, is enabled by default and shifts similarity scores to prioritize commodity code first, then text similarity, then country/region. This enhances mapping precision where commodity codes are available. If your ERP master data or LCA packages lack commodity codes, you can switch the option off to revert to text‚Äëmatching. Exact matches are elevated when product names and dataset names align and commodity codes are consistent (or both absent), even if descriptions are missing. To reduce false negatives, AI no longer pre‚Äëfilters by unit convertibility and you‚Äôll only be blocked at release if unit conversions are missing in product master data. And for categories with sparse activity‚Äëbased data, AI now includes spend‚Äëbased factors when they rank among the top 10 suggestions. For all details, check SAP Help: Using AI to Map Emission Factors to Purchased Products and Product Groups.

Refined AI-assisted Emission Factor Mapping with Enhanced Footprint Suggestions

 

Other Release Highlights

To help you better understand your transport network at a glance, we added map visualizations for locations and transport routes across key apps. In the Manage Locations app, you can view locations on an interactive map along with details such as address, geocoordinates, postal code, and country or region. The Manage Transport Activities app now also provides a map-based view of generated routes and legs, helping you visualize transport flows more intuitively. On top of that, the Manage Transport Activities and Calculate Transport Footprints apps include an enhanced quick view for locations with an embedded map display. This means you can access location details and see them on a map instantly, streamlining your workflow and saving time.

Visualization of Transport Route and Legs

In my previous blog post, I introduced the Source Input Items feature in the Manage Footprint Results app that gives granular visibility into the inputs driving product emissions to identify hotspots and guide targeted decarbonization actions. We now enhanced this feature with the ability to generate source input items for cyclical calculations. This makes footprint analysis more comprehensive, especially for products calculated based on cyclical processes. On SAP Help, you find more information about source input items: Viewing the Footprint Results, and examples on cycle calculations: Calculating Cycles.

Another update improves data handling and coverage in the Import Business Transactions app: You can now add business transaction data to supplement imported records, with clear tracking of imported and added entries. New columns ‚Äì Imported Records, Added Records, and Entry Method ‚Äì provide transparency on how data enters the system, ensuring complete coverage for footprint calculations. The consolidated data (imported and added records) is then used to calculate footprints. For details, see Import Business Transactions, and for more information about business transactions' behavior, see Business Transactions Types on SAP Help.

Finally, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management is now available in two additional regions: Europe (Frankfurt) and Brazil (S√£o Paulo), both on AWS. This expansion supports customers operating in these regions with improved availability and compliance.

 

Enablement Updates: Webinar, Learning Journey & Scenario Guide

To make it easier for you to adopt the latest capabilities, we‚Äôve expanded our enablement portfolio with new content and updates across multiple channels. Together with BearingPoint, we hosted a webinar that gives an overall introduction of SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and also takes a closer look at multi-impact categories and what they mean for your sustainability strategy. Supported by a system demo, the session explains how these new dimensions help you move beyond carbon to a more holistic view of environmental performance. If you missed it, you can watch the full recording here:

We‚Äôve also updated the Learning Journey Establishing Corporate Carbon Footprint Emissions with Advanced Configurations. A new unit now explains how to calculate GHG Scope 3.4 emissions using the ERP-centric transport footprint calculation capabilities introduced last year. This addition is particularly valuable for organizations looking to leverage existing ERP data for transport-related emissions without building parallel processes. It‚Äôs a practical guide to help you understand how these capabilities fit into your overall footprint model and reporting requirements.

In addition, we also published a new Scenario Guide that includes detailed process steps for calculating Scope 3.4 emissions based on data already available in your ERP systems: Process 8 ‚Äì Calculating Scope 3.4 Emissions Using Business Transaction Data.

These enablement updates are designed to make adoption easier and faster, so you can focus on turning sustainability data into actionable insights. Whether you prefer learning through webinars, structured journeys, or detailed guides, we‚Äôve got you covered.

 

BASF Coatings‚Äô Journey with SAP Sustainability Footprint Management

Recently, I joined the Inside SAP S/4HANA Cloud Podcast to discuss sustainability and share real-world examples of how our solutions create impact. A highlight was my conversation with Maximilian Bauer from BASF Coatings, who explained how they use SAP Sustainability Footprint Management to tackle the complexity of sustainability in their business.

BASF Coatings operates in a highly dynamic environment, producing thousands of product variations with every color shade counting as a new product. This creates massive data challenges when calculating footprints. With SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, BASF Coatings can now:

  • Scale and automate carbon footprint calculations for hundreds of thousands of products.
  • Integrate seamlessly into existing systems, embedding sustainability into daily operations.
  • Gain actionable insights to offer more sustainable products and make data-driven decisions.

As Maximilian Bauer said: ‚ÄúYou can only improve what you can measure ‚Äì and SAP Sustainability Footprint Management offers us exactly this.‚Äù

Looking ahead, BASF Coatings is moving beyond carbon to multi-impact footprints, covering categories like abiotic resource depletion to ensure responsible use of finite resources. They‚Äôre also scaling innovations such as biomass balance and ChemCycling¬Æ, replacing fossil-based raw materials with renewable or recycled alternatives. These steps position BASF to meet growing global demand for sustainable products and stay ahead of regulatory expectations.

BASF Coatings‚Äô journey illustrates why we‚Äôre evolving SAP Sustainability Footprint Management: from carbon-only to multi-impact sustainability footprints, enabling companies to manage risk, cost, and growth across multiple environmental dimensions ‚Äì all embedded in core business processes.

In the podcast, I also shared our broader vision: embedding sustainability into business processes, leveraging a single trusted data foundation, and using AI to make sustainability intelligent and scalable. By expanding beyond carbon toward multiple impact categories, we help businesses move from compliance to competitive advantage.

Listen to the full episode on Apple Podcast or Spotify.

 

Additional Information

For in-depth details on SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, including concepts, setup, and the application help, I recommend you browsing through the SAP Help Portal. For an overview of all new features and functions that have been released, check the What‚Äôs New section, which is updated with every new software release.

For exploring and experimenting in a live system, register for the free SAP Sustainability Footprint Management Trial. You‚Äôll receive an e-mail with access information within seconds after your registration and can then test the solution at your own convenience within a 30-day trial period. It also includes a wide range of guided tours designed to help you navigate through all the features and functions comprehensively. Recently, we also added new tours and will shortly release additional ones, representing the latest features and an enhanced user experience.

To stay up to date on SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, follow me here in the SAP Community. In regular cadence, I‚Äôll publish blog posts giving you updates on all the product‚Äôs new features and functions as well as deep dives into the product capabilities. I‚Äôm also looking forward to engaging with you directly, feel free to leave your feedback in the comment section.

entry.title: Re: Migration of legacy independent AUC with year end tra...
entry.content:
for AUC date it is noted: 

You cannot transfer the historical reference data of these transactions. Instead, the system uses the following data:

For a transfer at the end of the fiscal year (for example, 31.12.YYYY-1), the system always uses the first day of the current fiscal year that follows the year of the legacy data transfer (for example, 01.01.YYYY) as the asset value date.

For a legacy data transfer during the year (for example, 28.01.YYYY), the system always uses the first day of the fiscal year in the year of the legacy data transfer (for example, 01.01.YYYY).

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/3e5fcf2c768746049b5627bd5a42f720/bfd8d153c9684608e10000000a174cb4.html?locale=en-US&version=LATEST

This is standard behaviour and will not be changed by a Support incident. 

For reconciliation to legacy system you must take this into account that the AUC values will not be available until first day of new fiscal year in the new system. 
From the account determination on the AUC you can check to see if you can isolate on balance sheet while doing comparison.

entry.title: Re: How to Take SAP‚Äôs New Performance-Based Certification Exams
entry.content:
Thanks Dhillon for your questions and here is my answer:

  1. Case Study Availability: Just to clarify, was the case study provided, but I have heard of other having difficulty to locate within the platform?
    I faced a similar issue during my retake and some other learners reported the same issue but I know other could see it in their session. That was one of my points in Room for improvements. But you can always pause the AI session to check your session to see you can find it. Normally based on the instruction , I suggest not start the Avatar session before review and read the scenario and prepare your draft to follow during exam.
  2. Download Status: Were you eventually able to find the file, and if so, were you able to download it or you can only read it online?
    Downloading the scenario definitely available after the exam submitted & confirmed then you receive the AI analysis only during the session. You will not be able to access to that session later on.
  3. Material Access: Are the exam materials made available for review before pressing the 'Start' button, or only after the exam has begun?
    NO
  4. Time Limit Clarification: Could you please clarify the reference to '24 hours'? My understanding is that there is a 2-hour limit to complete the exam (BTP Solution Architect) once started, so I am unclear what the 24-hour window refers to.
    24 hours is the time range you have to take that exam otherwise you will lose one of your exam attmpts.2hr is the approximate time you have during that exam .This time comes handy specially if you failed because right away you can take another try of that exam as long as you are not passed that 2hr window.
  5. Exam Retake: Is it correct that if we fail the first attempt, we are permitted to retake the exam immediately, provided we have sufficient time remaining? Specifically, the 2-hour window covers both the initial attempt and any necessary retakes? In this case how can we restart the exam to ensure its counted within the same attempt?
    Yes 2 hr window covers the initial attempt and retake. You can just start from scratch the system will identify you still have time left (out of 2 hr ) and will allow you retake the exam without losing any exam attempts.
  6. Recording Procedures: If we are unable to find the required materials during the exam, are we permitted to stop the recording to search for them, or will stopping the recording end the session?
    You can pause the recording and start again after but I highly suggest to stop the recording and create a CASE for exam support team to address the issue
    Thanks,

entry.title: SAP Fiori Development newsletter January 2026 (issue #38)
entry.content:
Happy New Year. If 2025 was the year of AI, what will 2026 bring? Likely more AI.

Some predictions:

  1. Vibe coding will become more mainstream with MCP servers and LLMs working together to deliver more predictable and consistent results.
  2. We will start to see the emergence of the ‚Äúpost-app‚Äù era in enterprise software. I don‚Äôt think it will be entirely chat-based, but I do expect some parts to be generated on demand.
  3. The knowledge gap between developers who use AI and those who don‚Äôt will continue to grow. Now, the early adopters have a 1-year head start. For those who choose to remain on the sidelines, that will continue to grow. Don‚Äôt be that person ‚Äì you need to start experimenting with AI, even if you don‚Äôt include the results in your production code

What are your predictions for 2026? Let us know or add to the comments below. If you want to discuss your thoughts with your fellow developers, I encourage you to join our monthly SAP Fiori development roundtable. Register online or email me for an invitation.

Development News

The complete 6-part SAP Fiori Development Portal blog series
In this 6-part series, Katrin Polloczek and Marcel Waechter explore the SAP Fiori development portal and how to use it. Topics include SAP Fiori elements, building blocks, extension options, custom pages, and how all these pieces fit together. Read part 1 ‚Äì with links to all the posts.

SAP Fiori tools 2601 update ‚Äì Mobile Device Preview, Building Blocks, and AI-Driven Productivity
SAP Fiori tools 2601 includes enhancements for previewing applications, managing system connections, building SAP Fiori elements‚Äìbased UIs, and accelerating development with AI-powered tooling. In parallel, we continue to refine the fundamentals in security, modeling, and extensibility. See details.

Joule in SAP Build Code can now create freestyle UI5 apps
Last year, we introduced the SAPUI5 extension for the Joule coding assistant in SAP Build Code Over time, it has evolved to support conversion of UI5 apps to TypeScript and setting up new pages and the respective navigation. The latest improvement lets you create new freestyle UI5 apps according to your requirements, bringing the functionality right to developers using SAP Build Code‚Äîno other tools needed. Discover how it works.

Inside Joule: Lessons from building an AI coding assistant for SAP Build
This is a "making of" article about the implementation of the new /ui5-create-app slash command available within Joule in SAP Build Code. This new feature enables a conversation between an application developer and their AI assistant about building a new freestyle UI5 application. Learn more.

UI5 MCP Server's New TypeScript Migration Feature
The new UI5 MCP server will give you a massive head start on converting your existing JavaScript UI5 apps to TypeScript. A multi-day manual conversion becomes an hour of agent work plus several hours of polishing. The time savings add up with each project. Learn more.

Harmonizing UI5 URLs: Convenient URLs for SAPUI5/OpenUI5 CDN
When accessing the UI5 Demo Kit and when using UI5 in cloud scenarios, you use URLs like https://ui5.sap.com/. We are harmonizing these URLs to make them future-proof. See more details.

Events

SAP Fiori Innovation Day 2025 is a wrap. The final event in Walldorf included an overview of AI capabilities in SAP Cloud ERP, two hands-on exercises, and some great insights from the sponsoring partners. Learn the details.

We are planning more SAP Fiori Innovation Days in 2026. Watch your inbox for announcements about where and when we will be hosting these events.

entry.title: Issue with Data Authorization in Public Dimension of SAP Analytics Cloud Model
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

We have implemented a model in SAP Analytics Cloud which includes a public organizational dimension with a hierarchy composed of four levels: division, business unit, sub business unit, and cost center. A story is built on top of this model.

We have defined data authorizations on this hierarchy, intending to control access as follows:

1. Users can see all data
2. Users can see data for one or more specific divisions
3. Users can see data for one or more business units within specific divisions
4. Users can see data for one or more sub business units within specific business units
5. Users can see data for one or more cost centers within specific sub business units

However, we are encountering an issue where authorization filtering does not work correctly starting from the business unit level and below. For example, users assigned read permissions at the business unit level do not see any data in reports, even though data exists and users with broader permissions see the data as expected. This behavior also occurs for the more granular authorization scenarios (sub business unit and cost center levels).

Has anyone experienced similar issues, or is this a known limitation or configuration consideration in SAC related to hierarchical authorization on public dimensions? Any guidance or suggested troubleshooting actions would be greatly appreciated.

Thank you in advance for any support or insights you can provide.

entry.title: UTCTOLOCAL Function in Datasphere based on Plant TimeZone
entry.content:
We had the requirement from Business to convert the Date based on Plant's Mapped Local TimeZone. TimeZone is dynamic and picked up from TTZ5/TTZ5S table. Challenge was all the TimeZone mentioned in SAP table for plants wasn't working with UTCTOLOCAL function. 

This article provides instructions for installing and configuring timezone table in SAP Datasphere, including installing timezone tables (TTZD, TTZDF, TTZDV, TTZR, TTZZ) using Database Explorer and exporting them as per SNOTE 198411 and 1791342 with the export file HANATimezoneTables2023V02.tar.gz . It details modifying the SAP Datasphere Cloud ini configuration to set the default timezone schema and dataset, requiring SAP assistance due to Datasphere being hosted on public cloud, and checking timezone data in the sys.TIMEZONES view . The UTCTOLOCAL function is used to convert UTC to local timezones, and timezone mappings for specific plants can be retrieved from SAP standard tables TTZ5 or TTZ5S.

1. Using DataBase Explorer in Sap DataSphere install the TimeZone Table in Schema.
TTZD, TTZDF, TTZDV, TTZR, TTZZ

Refer the SNOTE 198411 and 1791342 for TimeZone Table export.

2. Check the Table in source once exported:

3.Change the parameter setting in ini configuration file. This would require SAP help as Datasphere is hosted on Public cloud.

a. Modify the default schema (mandatory in HANA Cloud, because SYSTEM schema cannot be used)

ALTER SYSTEM ALTER CONFIGURATION ('indexserver.ini', 'SYSTEM') SET ('global', 'timezone_default_data_schema_name') = 'SpaceNAME#SchemaName'  WITH RECONFIGURE;

b. Set 'sap' dataset to default (optional)

ALTER SYSTEM ALTER CONFIGURATION ('indexserver.ini', 'SYSTEM') SET ('global', 'timezone_dataset') = 'sap' WITH RECONFIGURE;

4. Check the data in sys.TimeZones View sap entries for TimeZone would have been populated. Plateform TimeZone entries by default available in the view. Post import of TimeZone Table sap TimeZone would reflect in TimeZones View.

Select * from sys. TIMEZONES;

5.Use the UTCTOLOCAL function to convert TimeZone to local Timezone.

We can get the TimeZone mapped to specific plants from Sap standard tables TTZ5 or TTZ5S

 

Hope This helps !!
Happy Learning  üôÇ

entry.title: News from SAP Activate SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602
entry.content:
We are pleased to announce the updates to SAP Activate, including the availability of eight roadmaps now offered in nine languages. We‚Äôre also excited to share the newly refreshed SAP Activate page on sap.com, which offers a clearer, more intuitive overview of the SAP Activate methodology. This release delivers a range of enhancements across SAP Activate assets, strengthening implementation guidance and improving usability. As always, our focus remains on simplifying and optimizing the implementation journey to provide a more seamless experience for our users. Below are the key highlights for this release:

  • Revamped SAP Activate page on SAP.com
  • Eight SAP Activate roadmaps Now Available in Nine Languages
  • SAP Activate Community Blogs and Activate Minute Videos
  • Updates to SAP Activate for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • Updates to SAP Activate for SAP Cloud ERP Private
  • Updates to SAP Activate for SAP Business Technology Platform
  • Updates to SAP Activate for Conversion of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2-system to 3-system landscape
  • Updates to SAP Activate for SAP SuccessFactors
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Test Automation Tool 2602 Release

 

Revamped SAP Activate page on SAP.com

We are excited to announce the launch of the revamped SAP Activate page on SAP.com! The updated experience delivers a clearer, more intuitive overview of the SAP Activate methodology, highlighting its phased approach, key benefits, real-world customer successes, and easy access to tools, road maps, and learning resources. Whether you‚Äôre just starting your cloud journey or deep into an implementation, the refreshed page makes it easier than ever to understand how SAP Activate helps accelerate transformation and drive faster time-to-value. Explore the new page here and see how SAP Activate continues to evolve to support your success.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Eight SAP Activate roadmaps Now Available in Nine Languages

SAP Activate roadmap content is now available in nine languages, making it easier for our users to consume guidance in the language they are most comfortable with. They can now access roadmap text in German, Spanish, Portuguese, French, Italian, Chinese, Japanese, Korean, and English directly within SAP for ME. This is enabled through Machine Translation, which is now available across eight roadmaps:

  • SAP Activate for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • SAP Activate for SAP Cloud ERP Private ‚Äì New Implementation
  • SAP Activate for SAP Cloud ERP Private ‚Äì System Conversion
  • SAP Activate for SAP Cloud ERP Private ‚Äì Selective Data Transition
  • SAP Activate for SAP Cloud ERP Private ‚Äì Upgrade
  • SAP Activate for SAP Business Technology Platform
  • SAP Activate for Conversion of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (2-system to 3-system)
  • SAP Activate for New Cloud Implementations (Public Cloud ‚Äì General)

For more details, refer to the blog.

 

SAP Activate Community | SAP Activate Blogs | SAP Activate Minute Videos

Join the SAP Activate Community to explore valuable content and resources while connecting with SAP partners, clients and internal colleagues by participating in discussions and sharing knowledge.

Make sure to follow the SAP Activate tag to access blog posts like those highlighted here, along with additional insights shared by SAP Activate experts within the community.

Recap of some blog posts from the community:

  • Introducing the SAP Activate for SAP Business Network for Logistics roadmap by Ana Goetze
  • SAP Cloud ALM for Operations Content Now Available in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Road Map by Nicole Fuller
  • Deliver quality SAP BTP projects with SAP Activate and partner support services by Jose Bastidas
  • How the Transition to SAP Cloud ALM Roadmap Answers Your Top 5 Transition Questions by Ana Goetze
  • Who are you? Accountable or Responsible when standing for in the Fit-to-Standard process? by Jair Azevedo
  • RISE with SAP Methodology: A Practical Guide to Modernizing with Confidence by Manuel Lederle
  • Deep Dive: Inside the Framework of RISE with SAP Methodology by Manuel Lederle
  • SAP Activate for RISE with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition: Scenario-Specific Roadmaps by Kristen Reddington
  • Video: Best Practices to keep up to date on updates and changes in SAP Activate by Jan Musil

 

Updates of SAP Activate for SAP S/HANA Cloud Public Edition in 2602

The SAP Activate for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud implementation roadmap has been enhanced based on product management input, system functionality changes, and customer feedback. Below are highlights for this release.

  • Added guidance for system monitoring using SAP Cloud ALM which includes Business Process Monitoring, Integration & Exception Monitoring, User Monitoring, Job & Automation Monitoring, and Health Monitoring. Production Operations Monitoring in SAP Cloud ALM
  • Expanded the road maps to include a new run phase quality gate and consolidated the adoption plan checklists with the remaining phase gates. All quality gate questions are available as a form in SAP Cloud ALM with enhanced integration to delivery services. Conduct Project Quality Gate for Run Phase
  • Introduced Joule in road map viewer and Joule for Consultants based on Activate content making it more efficient for the customer to find information that they are looking for. 
  • Added a tag to identify the tasks required for the GROW Fast initiative where customers can go live with a fixed scope in 6 weeks.
  • Enhanced the Upgrade of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition to include detail related to downward compatibility. Importing configuration transports older than 1 release require SAP support. 3610869 - 3-System Landscape: Downward Compatibility Rule
  • Enable machine translations to provide the content via Road Map Viewer in 6 languages.
  • Included Business AI into the overall implementation methodology by providing easy access to the AI-powered scenarios at the time that they are needed.

 

Updates of SAP Activate for Cloud ERP Private

SAP Activate, the standardized framework for RISE with SAP Methodology, has been enhanced with numerous updates, which are listed in detail in the release notes. The most notable enhancements are the additions of WalkMe and the Transformation Preparation Service, as well as improvements to clean core governance, guidance, and measurement using the RISE with SAP Methodology Dashboard. Additionally, the roadmap viewer has been enhanced with Joule for information retrieval and language translations of SAP Activate content to eight languages, in addition to the content source in English.

Key highlights include:

  • Updated all accelerators to reflect the latest SAP S/4HANA 2025 release content, ensuring alignment with current release, guidance, and best practices across the SAP Activate methodology. 
  • Enhanced guidance for SAP Business Transformation Center by updating tasks, procedure steps, and accelerators to better support selective data transition execution.  
  • Enhanced UX Adoption and User Experience guidance, including updated UX workshops, value discovery accelerators, launchpad design guidance, and stronger linkage between UX strategy and Fit-to-Standard activities. We have updated several tasks to highlight the fact that FIORI/UX is the foundation for Clean Core and AI (like Joule). Additional details available via the User Experience tag.
  • Added a new Mix-and-Match (Selective Data Transition) guidance by updating and tagging key tasks across Prepare to Realize, adding a dedicated tag for Selective Data Transition in Mix-and-Match Scenario. 
  • Refresh of the Project Management workstream, updating purposes, procedures, and templates for governance, planning, sprint execution, phase closure, and multi-country delivery to improve lifecycle consistency. 
  • Expanded extensibility and analytics guidance, adding new accelerators and clearer procedures for key-user extensibility, classic extensibility, embedded analytics discovery, and initial analytics setup. 
  • Improved enablement and learning tasks, with new accelerators for learning needs analysis, enablement strategy, content development, WalkMe solution planning, and removal of redundant or outdated enablement steps. 
  • Refined system conversion and cutover execution clarity, including renamed tasks, updated conversion runbooks, improved readiness assessment guides, clearer cutover procedures, and better differentiation between sandbox, development, test, and production activities.

See the release notes for a complete list of all improvements. 

 

Updates of SAP Activate for SAP Business Technology Platform

We‚Äôre excited to announce new content in the SAP Activate for SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) that guides customers on how to design and develop solutions using SAP AI capabilities within SAP BTP. The roadmap now covers the following topics:

  • Incorporate AI and generative AI considerations while shaping the overall SAP BTP implementation approach and governance model
  • Identify where SAP AI services fit within the BTP account structure, environments, and development setup
  • Enable teams to explore AI capabilities alongside core BTP services during early self-learning and sandbox activities
  • Apply AI patterns during application design using ABAP Cloud, CAP, and SAP Build
  • Extend applications with Joule to deliver conversational and productivity-driven user interactions

 

Updates of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2-system landscape to 3-system landscape 

We are excited to share the latest improvements to the SAP Activate guidance for our customers converting their SAP S/4HANA Cloud from a 2-system landscape to a 3-system landscape. Since the last major release in August 2025, we have made several updates to the guidance based on the learnings from conversion projects and improvements to the conversion process. The key updates are outlined below:

  • Updated task Verify Authorizations in SAP for Me - updated procedure steps and accelerators.
  • Updated task Create and Schedule Test Plan and linked it to the task ‚ÄúCreate Test Strategy".
  • Updated task Identify Integrations Scenarios for setup on Test System in the procedure section to explain rebuilding integrations manually or using automation tools.
  • Updated task Create Solution Test Plans with new accelerator for SAP Cloud ALM for Implementation Expert Portal - Test Management.

In addition to the updates mentioned above, the Joule assistant in the road map viewer app has been enabled to support our users with 2SL to 3SL conversion-related questions. When you prompt Joule, remember to include ‚Äú2SL to 3SL conversion‚Äù in the prompt for higher quality results.

We recommend that all users preparing for the upcoming conversion project review the detailed release notes in the SAP Activate road map viewer for the latest content updates and view the conversion overview video on the Overview page of the conversion roadmap here.

 

Updates of SAP Activate for SAP SuccessFactors

The SAP Activate for SAP SuccessFactors roadmap has been enhanced based on product management input, system functionality changes, and customer feedback. Below are the highlights:

  • Introduced a quality gate checklist to the end of each phase. All quality gates are available as an interactive form in SAP Cloud ALM and enables enhanced integration to delivery services processes. Conduct Project Quality Gate for Prepare Phase
  • Simplified the task Add Super Admin Access to the SuccessFactors Instance based on process improvements. Linked directly to the help documentation for guidance.
  • Updated Determine Test Scope and other testing related tasks to utilize a process that is standard across multiple solutions.

Added references to SAP WalkMe to increase visibility on how SAP WalkMe can help during the implementation.

 

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Test Automation Tool 2602 Release

The CE2602 release introduces significant enhancements to Post Upgrade Testing (PUT), including advanced comparison capabilities, improved Test Data Container (TDC) AutoBind integration, and a new scoping capability in i-TS for Smart Execution. Together, these improvements enable smarter automation, more flexible test coverage, and a simplified test setup experience.

Key highlights include:

  • Full Scope Comparison (PUT)
    • Comprehensive Analysis: Compare two complete PUT executions (standard and custom) across different releases or test runs.
    • Side-by-Side Summary: Review execution summaries, triggers, and timestamps in a consolidated view.
    • Impact Identification: Quickly identify post-upgrade changes across the full PUT landscape to support validation and risk mitigation.
  • Comparison of Custom Automates (PUT)
    • Cross-Run Comparison: Compare custom automated PUT test plans executed across two different runs.
    • Instance-Level Status: View detailed execution statuses for each test plan, including Success, Failed, Pre-checks Failed, and Cancelled.
  • Enhanced AutoBind for Test Data Container Integration
    • Intelligent Mapping: Enhanced AutoBind logic automatically maps TDC fields to script labels for both standard and PUT automations.
    • Improved Accuracy: Ensures precise alignment between test data and test scripts.
    • Reduced Manual Effort: Minimizes manual configuration, accelerating test setup.
  • Scoping Capability in i-TS (Smart Execution)
    • Comprehensive Coverage: Combine i-TS recommended processes with standard and custom-defined processes when executing a custom PUT variant, reducing test scope gaps.
    • Flexible Execution: Selectively merge scopes to create a unified test run tailored to specific testing needs.
    • Improved Accuracy: Validates critical i-TS recommended scenarios alongside custom flows for a more reliable post-upgrade assessment.

Overall, these enhancements significantly improve testing efficiency, increase data accuracy, reduce manual effort, and boost productivity across post-upgrade test automation workflows.

Please share with us your feedback and questions in the comments to this blog post or directly via the feedback function in the SAP Activate road map viewer on SAP for Me.

Run simple ‚Äì SAP Activate ‚Äì Accelerate and simplify the adoption of SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

cf ssh -L 63306:<host_from_service_key>:<port_from_service_key> <application_name>

Adding SSL reject unauthorized to the credentials worked. 

"ssl": {

}
Any idea you get what i possibly did wrong.

entry.title: Re: SAP S/4HANA Business Partner - VAT Registration Code check switch off (CMD_API007 or VMD_API043)
entry.content:
@Andi_M 

We have implemented the solution. However, because the general error message does not pop-up anymore, SAP triggers the s-called post processing office (PPO) mechanism. The update of the customer-specific data is delayed (occurs technically "on commit"), while all non-customer-specific business partner data are updated directly after pressing the save button. Due to the removal of the error in the custom functional module as proposed above, it is not possible any more during "COMMIT WORK" processing. Because of this errors that occur during processing of customer-specific data are saved in PPO and the corresponding customer-specific database tables are not updated. In the BP transaction, this leads to the following error message when saving: 

 

In MDS_PPO2 transaction you can see the following for business process CVI_03:

So the suggested solution in this blog solves one part, but as a result the PPO is triggered and the creation of the BP Person is still triggered.

 

Could you assist? 

 

Thank you!

entry.title: How to Setup Local Accounting Principle as Group Accounting Principle in S/4HANA Cloud (Ledger 4G)
entry.content:
Problem
With scope item 5W2 for Group Valuation, ledger 4G is deployed. On initial deployment the ledger is not enabled with an Accounting Principle assigned. This step must be complete before the system can be used, until the step is complete the system will trigger errors. 

Assignment of Accounting Principles can prove problematic, an acceptable combination that the system will allow can cause issues so this blog we want to give some guidance with more explanation on the recommendations from scenario 5 in KBA 3530183 - Assigning Accounting Principles to Ledgers and Company Codes in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: Details on Configuration in General Ledger Accounting and Asset Accounting 

Resolving
Ledger Level Accounting Principle Assignment

  • Leading Ledger 0L - Corp Accounting Principle IFRS
    https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0fa84c9d9c634132b7c4abb9ffdd8f06/8a4fd7531a4d424de10000000a174cb4.html?locale=en-US&version=LATEST "For these reasons, the leading ledger can act as the global ledger for the whole entity (that is, with the valuation done according to legal reporting requirements)."
  • Non Leading Ledger 2L ‚Äì Local Accounting Principle (blank at Ledger Level)
  • Non Leading Ledger 3L ‚Äì Corp Accounting Principle USGP
  • Non Leading Ledger 4G (Group Reporting) ‚Äì IFRS

In this scenario IFRS is used on Leading Ledger 0L, it is possible to exchange USGP for IFRS on the Leading Ledger, whichever Accounting Principle is assigned on Leading Ledger must be assigned on Ledger 4G.

Company Code Local Accounting Principle Assignment (Ledger 2L)

  • This gives flexibility to add additional company codes and additional Local Accounting Principles at a later time if needed.
  • Statistical Depreciation Areas are active only when Local Accounting Principle is assigned at Company Code Level.

With these settings scenario 5 will be complete as per KBA above, allowing posting, asset creation etc. 

"Image/data in this Blog are from SAP internal systems, sample data, or demo systems. Any resemblance to real data is purely coincidental."

entry.title: üá©üá™ SAP CodeJam ABAP Cloud & ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model ‚Äì SPECIAL EDITION
entry.content:
In this SPECIAL EDITION of the ABAP Cloud & RAP CodeJam,  we want to address the experienced RAP developer that wants to learn first hand from our experts about the newest features that have been added to the RAP framework with the 2511 and the upcoming 2602 releases including:

  • Collaborative Draft
  • Draft Scope
  • Recommendations
  • Editable Treeview
  • Analytical Table (Read-Only)

The features will be presented upfront so that the participants can decide which feature(s) they want to implement by just using the Develop Applications section of our SAP Online Help.

As said this event is NOT suited for absolute beginners since we expect that the participants have a solid knowledge of ABAP Cloud and the development of RAP business objects.   Please do not register if you do not fit within this profile. 

This is an in-person event only (not virtual) and is planned for Friday 20th February 2026 in St.Leon-Rot (near the SAP mothership in Walldorf) from 10:00 - 16:00 CET.   The language and content of the event will be in English.

 

Location:  SAP SE,   Building ROT03.   SAP-Allee 27   68789 St. Leon-Rot Germany

For more information about how to get to the event, please check 240319_20_sap_rot_how_to_find_us.pdf

Please note that spaces are limited - we can only accommodate 35 attendees.

 If you wish to attend, register by clicking the Yes button in the Will you be attending? section above to the right. Two weeks before the event, we will ask you to confirm your attendance.

 

The instructors are Andre Fischer and several colleagues from the ABAP Platform Development Unit. We will provide an SAP BTP ABAP Environment system with the latest 2602 release.  Please be sure to have the LATEST ADT installed  https://developers.sap.com/tutorials/abap-install-adt..html

 

We plan to collect feedback for the documentation and materials being used in the hands-on using issues in  Github.com, so please create a Github.com account in order to leverage that important feedback channel during the workshop.

entry.title: Re: IAS Login Name dependencies
entry.content:

entry.title: In MTO, SO field in Planned/Purchase Req. is taking quotation/Inquiry no. of Reference Sales Order.
entry.content:
Hello Team,

In MTO scenarios, the generated Planned order/ Purchase Requisition number having the account assignment section where Sales Order field is available is taking the reference of Inquiry/Quotation number for the respective Sales Order. It also results in impacting the report of sales Order based output details.

As per business requirment, the client is expecting the output based on the Sales Order not on the basis of Inquiry/Quotation number for Assigned Sales Order. 

Please suggest how to map the scenario to get the desired result output, without impacting the other modules fundamental concepts like as Costing, Delivery and all.

Also, suggest the advantages and disadvantages of the other functionalities.

How to execute/re-run the SDMI Class to migrate the newly added rows
entry.content:
Hi SAP,

Could you please let us know on how to execute/re-run for a single migration class?


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How to execute/re-run the SDMI Class to migrate the n...
entry.content:
Steps for systems which are before release  release S/4HANA 1909 (SAP_BASIS 7.54) 

  1. Open t-code SDM_MON
  2. Click on 'Current Client info' button
  3. Edit
  4. Restart finished Migration. 

Steps for systems which are after release  release S/4HANA 1909 (SAP_BASIS 7.54) 

  1. Open t-code SE24
  2. Choose Object Type 'CL_SDM_UTILS'
  3. Execute
  4. Choose Method 'RESET_MIGRATION_STATUS
  5. Click on execute
  6. Fill IV_CLIENT parameter with the affected client (for example 200)
  7. Fill IV_MIGRATION_CLASS with the affected migration class (for example: CL_NGC_CORE_SDM_DATUB_CABN)
  8. If multiple migration classes are affected, the process has to be done for all migration classes
  9. If multiple clients are affected, parameter IV_CLIENT can be left blank, and IV_INCL_CROSS_CLT_ACTION has to be flagged
  10. Execute

The following steps are the same for all releases 

  1. Open t-code SE38
  2. Choose report R_SDM_ONLINE_EXEC
  3. Click on execute
  4. Fill out the selection criteria (Name of migration class, Max. no. of parallel threads    =   4, All checkboxes must be unchecked! )
  5. Execute

Intercompany posting having intra company entries. Can we create a Admin Company?
entry.content:
For one of our middle east Country operations, we have a total of 8 company codes ‚Äì Sao Company code A till company code H.
Now the company code A behaves as both an Admin company and an operating company.

So, for example when we do an allocation for a budget/expense, The funds are initially in Company code A and is the allocated to all other company code including self(via a separate profit center).

So when we post an intercompany accounting document , for example an allocation document, - the resultant document is a bit confusing as :
- Every IC Trading partner (TP D, C, D‚Ä¶.) is now having a transaction with 2 profit centers of the Company code A 

In the entry view of this document, the 1st line is debited from and then paid -

and then to 7 other trading partner (i.e. other company codes)

entry.title: How to make standard Fiori apps open an extended Fiori app instead of the standard one?
entry.content:
Hello experts, good morning.

I would like to ask for your guidance regarding an issue we are facing while extending a standard Fiori application.

Context:
We were asked to extend a standard app in order to adjust a specific parameter within it. To achieve this, we used a SAPUI5 Adaptation Project from SAP Business Application Studio (BAS).

The required adjustments were successfully implemented, and the app was deployed correctly to our system. After that, the necessary Catalog, Group, and Role were created so the extended app could be used.

Initially, a custom (Z) Target Mapping was created for the extended app, based on the standard app‚Äôs target mapping, and everything was working as expected.

However, we later identified the following issue:

The standard app can be launched from other standard Fiori applications. When this navigation occurs, the standard app is always opened, but our requirement is for the extended app to be opened instead, so the requested change can be used.

To address this, we tried modifying the Target Mapping, keeping the same semantic object (or at least the same name), and removing the original target mapping, so that the apps performing the navigation would open the extended app.

This approach worked partially. For some users, the navigation opens the extended app correctly. However, when testing with other users who have more roles and profiles assigned, the system still opens the standard app instead of the extended one.

Additionally, we tried using the ‚ÄúAdd SAP Fiori Launchpad Config‚Äù option available in SAP BAS:

However, this option does not seem to work, may be deprecated, or not supported in our system, as we receive a ‚ÄúURL Not Found‚Äù error.

In summary, my main question is:

How can I make standard Fiori applications open the extended app instead of the standard one?

We have already tried adjusting the target mapping and exploring Launchpad configurations, but without complete success. At this point, we have run out of ideas and would really appreciate any guidance.

Do you know of any alternative approach, recommended solution, or documentation that could help in this scenario?

Thank you for your time and for reading my question.
I look forward to your comments.

Best regards,
EBZ

entry.title: Re: Additional fields for Defects Management in Cloud ALM?

Hi, Bruno,
I believe you are looking to add custom fields in the actual Defect itself-> this is not possible.

If you have a request for a feature/function that is not presently available, you can submit it at:

 - SAP Cloud ALM for Implementation  https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/campaign/3501
- SAP Cloud ALM for Operations https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/campaign/3525

See Customizable defect management to meet common practice needs
Request ID: 319793

(Just an aside:  If you would like to control the fields used in filtering which Defects appear, Adapt Filters does allow for additional fields to be added, though they are NOT custom.)

Best regards,
Paula

entry.title: Re: Which process log to the XI_SEC_MSG table?
entry.content:
Hello, 

This is generally related to the security configurations in the SOAP Adapter (also similar configuration options exist in other channel types). 
"SOAP messages can be secured either by using Web service security (signature only) or S/MIME standards (signature and encryption)." 
If the Security Profile option for either Web Services Security or S/MIME is enabled in the channel (see below screenshot), then these messages are written to the XI_SEC_MSG table. These entries must then be archived. 

Regards
Mark

entry.title: Re: How to use the OData Client Proxy in SAP S/4 HANA or How to use the OData Service Consumption Mo
entry.content:
I have finally managed to create a remote proxy using OData V4.

The key is the proxy factory class.

You will have to use this class /iwbep/cl_cp_client_proxy_fact instead of /iwbep/cl_cp_factory_remote.

@wagener-mark: Have you managed it? What is your problem with 

cl_http_client=>create_by_destination

You just have to use it like this and then call the proxy factory. Either for V2 or V4.

cl_http_client=>create_by_destination( 
    exporting  destination = 'RemoteConnection'
    importing  client      = client ).

Btw.: I've developed the proxy with S4HANA2023 FSP02.
